title: Curriculum review: back to basics or back to the future?
text:
"I did 14 town hall-style meetings, and what teachers said to me is it's not enough to be teaching knowledge and traditional content. We need young people who can solve problems and think creatively. We need to teach for the future."

In his introduction to the review, he said the proportion of NSW 15-year-olds

meeting minimally acceptable standards of reading, mathematics and scientific literacy has been in steady decline based on PISA assessments between 2000 and 2015 (the latest available).

But the report went on to say: "Although depth and breadth of learning are both important, the proposed changes preference deeper conceptual understanding over shallower coverage of extensive factual and procedural detail."

Dr Masters rejected a suggestion there was a conflict between weakness in reading and numeracy and a solution based on objectives such as critical thinking.

Education program director at the Centre for Independent Studies Fiona Mueller said looking at single issue such as curriculum was not the way to reform education.

This is once again an attempt to fix education by looking at one aspect. — Dr Fiona Mueller, Centre for Independent Studies

"This is once again an attempt to fix education by looking at one aspect. But the majority of teachers are battling to keep kids in their seats. It's putting the cart way ahead of the horse."

Dr Masters said the curriculum was overcrowded, as responsibilities that once belonged to families or churches had been given to schools

Teachers said this meant they were presenting "dot points" to students and skating across the surface rather than teaching deeply.

He recommended the education curriculum be pared back and teachers given a smaller core of content for most subjects.

Dr Masters proposed a new assessment structure based on a "sequence of attainment levels" although Dr Mueller said this would require "an enormous effort in the professional development of teachers", adding to their workload instead of reducing it.
description: The NSW Premier says education report is back to basics, but the author says it is about thinking creatively.
